Dear Ms. Canales:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM, and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Several youth dress and dance provocatively in front of a staff
member. The staff member has followed youth into the bathroom
individually, having sexual contact with them.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 5/23/2025.
Complainant reported after reporting the initial allegations, she
gathered more information and Youth A was the youth Staff 1 was
allegedly taking into the bathroom. Complainant reported Youth A
reportedly would go into the bathroom and Staff 1 would follow
Youth A into the bathroom and remain in the bathroom with Youth
A for a little while. Complainant did not know dates this occurred
however it was reported to have occurred “often”. Complainant
reported no further information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and MSP
Trooper. Youth A reported she had no concerns with Staff 1 until
Staff 1 placed her in a restraint as Youth A reported Staff 1
restrained her from behind which Youth A reported was
“triggering” as she has been sexually abused in the past. Youth A
reported Staff 1’s private area was near her buttocks area as he
was standing behind her per the restraint model technique.
However, it “triggered” her, and she responded by punching Staff
1 multiple times. Youth A reported Staff 1 did not do anything
wrong or inappropriate during the restraint, but the fact that she
was restrained by a male upset her. Youth A reported she has not
liked Staff 1 since this restraint. Youth A denied anything sexual
2

happening between her and Staff 1. Youth A reported a former
youth, Youth E, was spreading rumors about her and Staff 1
“dating” which Youth A reported was a lie. Youth A reported Staff
1 never touched her inappropriately. Youth A reported one time
the former youth, Youth E, told her Staff 1 was staring at her butt
when Youth A was “twerking” which Youth A reported was a
dance. Youth A reported she saw Staff 1 staring at her when she
was “twerking” and Staff 1 told her if she did not stop the
inappropriate dance, she would be given an STT (Special
Treatment Team referral) which Youth A reported was behavior
paperwork when youth do something inappropriate at the facility.
Youth A reported Staff 1 has never gone into the bathroom with
her.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported no concerns with Staff 1. Youth B reported once Staff 1
came out of the bathroom, and she noticed his pants zipper was

reported she feels comfortable around Staff 1. Youth B reported
Youth A and a former youth, Youth E, who is no longer at the

A and Staff 1 having any inappropriate relationship. Youth B
reported she has never witnessed Staff 1 follow any youth into the
bathroom at the facility.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025. Youth C reported she has no concerns with Staff 1’s
boundaries with any youth at the facility and has never witnessed
Staff 1 to take any youth into the bathroom.
Youth D was attempted to be interviewed twice face-to-face at
the facility on 5/14/2025 and refused to speak with MDHHS
Worker and Consultant both times.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor
reported she has no concerns with Staff 1. Supervisor reported
she has heard youth complain regarding how Staff 1 will over
explain things to them which youth tend to get frustrated with, but
no other concerns. Supervisor reported a prior youth, Youth E, at
the facility who is no longer there, made threats prior to leaving
the facility stating she was going to go after Staff 1 as Staff 1 had
3

pressed charges on her for assaulting him and the Youth E was
mad about it. Supervisor reported Youth A tends to dance
inappropriately at the facility and is redirected when she does.
Supervisor reported no knowledge of Staff 1 ever going into the
bathroom with any youth, including Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1
reported the youth at the facility act inappropriately by dancing
inappropriately, using vulgar language, and dressing
inappropriately, which requires him to have to redirect these
behaviors. Staff 1 reported youth at the facility are not allowed to
“twerk” dance and are required to wear clothing that covers their

no crop tops, and shorts are to be past their fingertips. Staff 1
reported when the youth do not follow the rules of talking,

reported Youth A tends to be “provocative” as well as there was

watching Youth A “twerk” for enjoyment and rather has redirected

denied ever following any youth alone into the bathroom at the
facility. Staff 1 reported the only time he was in the bathroom with
a youth was when Youth B was going to self-harm and a female
staff was present with him. Staff 1 denied ever seeking a sexual
relationship with Youth A or any youth at the facility. Staff 1
reported he restrained Youth A as Youth A punched him. Staff 1
reported Youth A told him she was “triggered” by him restraining
her as he was a male staff. Staff 1 reported Youth A calmed down
quickly, and he released her from the restraint quickly.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2
reported she normally works with Staff 1 at the facility and has no
concerns with Staff 1’s boundaries with youth. Staff 2 reported
Staff 1 sets boundaries with youth and does not go into youth’s
bedrooms or near the bathroom when youth are using the

any youth to the bathroom. Staff 2 reported several youth have
complained about Staff 1, including Youth C and Youth D, as they
do not like Staff 1. Staff 2 reported one time Staff 1 bent over and
“his crack” showed when he bent over, and the youth complained.
Staff 2 reported Youth A tends to dance inappropriately at the
4

witnessed Staff 1 to stare or look at Youth A inappropriately,
rather he may look at Youth A to redirect her behavior.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 6
reported she has no concerns with Staff 1’s boundaries with youth
or concerns of Staff 1 being in any sexual relations with youth.
Staff 6 reported she has never seen or heard any concerns of
Staff 1 following any youth into the bathroom at the facility. Staff 6
reported she has never witnessed or heard any concerns of Staff
1 looking at youth in an inappropriate manner when youth are
dancing inappropriately at the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 4
reported she has worked with Staff 1 and has no concerns
regarding Staff 1. Staff 4 reported she feels Staff 1 is a “great
worker” and sets boundaries with the youth. Staff 4 reported

firm boundaries and holds youth accountable and in turn youth get
mad and make false allegations regarding Staff 1. Staff 4
reported she has never had any concerns regarding Staff 1’s
boundaries with youth and/or any concerns regarding Staff 1
being in a sexual relationship with any youth at the facility,
including Youth A. Staff 4 reported Staff 1 is very aware of his
role in a female facility and does not enter youth bedrooms without
a female staff present to watch and will typically have female staff

bathroom at the facility. Staff 4 reported Youth A does not care for
Staff 1 due to Staff 1 setting firm boundaries and holding her
accountable for her actions.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 5
reported she works with Staff 1 occasionally and has no concerns
with Staff 1. Staff 5 reported she has no concerns with Staff 1’s
boundaries with any youth at the facility including Youth A. Staff 5
reported she has never witnessed or heard any concerns of Staff
1 following any youth into the bathroom at the facility including
Youth A. Staff 5 reported Staff 1 sets clear boundaries with youth
at the facility and when youth are dancing inappropriately, Staff 1
will look away and tell the youth to stop. Staff 5 reported Youth A
has come downstairs dressed inappropriately and described a
time when Youth A came downstairs with no bra on under her
shirt and Staff 1 immediately looked away and addressed the
5

concern by telling Youth A to go back upstairs and dress
appropriately.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 6/3/2025. Staff 3
reported she has worked with Staff 1 on occasion and has no
concerns with Staff 1’s boundaries with youth at the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Opportunities Employee Handbook Youth-Staff
Boundaries: Of the utmost importance for employees
working in a residential setting with youth are appropriately
managed relationships with the youth that we serve. Staff
are expected to exhibit and maintain ethical and
professional behavior. This includes interacting with youth
in a manner that promotes their emotional and physical
safety and incorporates trauma responsive practices.
Under no circumstance is an employee, regardless of
position, to do any of the following: Employees are never to
enter into personal or sexual relationships with a resident or
recently released youth.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: Staff 1 had two disciplines,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 1 received Standards
of Conduct and Professionalism training during his new hire
orientation training dated 10/3/2024.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as based on staff and youth
interviews, there was no inappropriate sexual relationship
occurring between Staff 1 and Youth A. All staff and youth
interviewed also denied any inappropriate relationships or
interactions occurring from Staff 1 towards any youth at the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Allegation Staff come to work smelling of marijuana. Staff have vapes,
marijuana dabs, and a lighter torch used to smoke marijuana dabs
in his car at the facility.
Investigation Interviews:

ago she saw marijuana paraphernalia in Staff 1’s car including
“dabs” sitting in the cup holder, a butane lighter torch on the front
seat, and vapes. Youth A reported she did not know if Staff 1’s
car doors were locked as she did not try to open Staff 1’s car
doors.

5/14/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B

once, unable to recall when, and took a vape from Staff 1’s car.
Youth B reported Youth A threw the vape into the woods.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025. Youth C reported Staff 1 smells like marijuana “all the

Worker and Consultant.

8

Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
5/28/2025. Chief Administrator reported the youth at the facility
target Staff 1 and have made multiple allegations regarding Staff 1
smelling of marijuana, which is false. Chief Administrator reported
she has never smelled marijuana on Staff 1, nor has she had any
concerns of Staff 1 coming to work under the influence of any
substances. Chief Administrator reported the facility does not
allow substance use or tolerate that behavior of staff. Chief
Administrator reported no knowledge of any incidents where
Youth A went into Staff 1’s car or took anything from Staff 1’s car.
Chief Administrator reported staff are to always have their car
doors locked at the facility. Chief Administrator reported no
knowledge of Staff 1 ever having vapes, dabs, or a torch of any
sort in his car as these items are not allowed on facility grounds as
the facility is a drug free zone. Chief Administrator reported an
STT (Special Treatment Team referral) is a write up of youth
behaviors that is reviewed by administration and administration
meets with the youth to discuss the concerns and come up with a
plan to address the behavioral concerns in the STT.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 5
reported she has never smelled marijuana on Staff 1 when he has
come to work, nor has she had any concerns of Staff 1 being
under the influence of any substances. Staff 5 reported she has
never heard anything regarding Youth A getting into Staff 1’s car
and taking anything from Staff 1’s car. Staff 5 reported the
facilities policy is for car doors to be locked and the facility
administration will randomly check staff car doors to ensure doors
are locked without staff knowing. Staff 5 reported she has never
seen any vapes, dabs, torch lighters in Staff 1 car. Staff 5
reported she has been in Staff 1’s car on occasion to run to the
gas station and has never seen any items that should not be on

Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 6/3/2025. Staff 3
reported she has smelled marijuana on Staff 1 in the morning

Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Opportunities Employee Handbook Standards of
Conduct: Staff are always expected to maintain ethical and
professional behavior. This includes the expectation that
staff are to interact with youth in a manner promoting their
emotional and physical safety while incorporating trauma
responsive practices. While not intended to list all the forms
of behavior that are considered unacceptable in the
workplace, the following are examples of rule infractions or
misconduct that may result in disciplinary action, including
termination of employment: Working under the influence of
alcohol or illegal drugs.
• Youth Opportunities Employee Handbook Standards of
Conduct: behavior that are considered unacceptable in the
workplace include working under the influence of alcohol or
illegal drugs, and possession, distribution, sale, transfer, or
use of alcohol or illegal drugs in the workplace.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: Staff 1 had two disciplines,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 1 received Standards
of Conduct and Professionalism training during his new hire
orientation training dated 10/3/2024.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance regarding the allegations of
Staff 1 coming to work smelling of marijuana and Staff 1 having
vapes, dabs, and a butane torch in his car at the facility, the facility
is found in compliance as there is not enough information to
support a rule violation. Per interviews with Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Staff 3, Staff 1 has come to work smelling of
marijuana however interviews with Supervisor, Chief
Administrator, Staff 2, Staff 4, Staff 5, and Staff 6 all report they
have never smelled marijuana on Staff 1. Staff 1 denied ever
using marijuana prior to his shift or coming to work smelling of
marijuana. There is not enough information to support Staff 1 has
come into work under the influence of substances. Per interviews
regarding Staff 1 having vapes, dabs, and a butane torch in his
car at the facility, Youth A and Youth B were the only interviews
that indicted this, and all other interviews indicated no such items
have been viewed in Staff 1’s car.
10

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to retrain staff on the facilities
substance use policy, and the facility being a drug free campus.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a
youth’s background or appearance or mental state. Yelling,
threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.

IV. RECOMMENDATION
